title: How should I invest 5 lakh rupees for maximum returns and minimize tax ? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is important for you to understand that maximum returns can only come with maximum risk. Nothing is ever zero risk. No matter how well you understand an investment, equity is always risky. The risk component can be high or low but it's always there. Among mutual funds, equity funds can provide highest returns if you continue investing for long term. However, these funds face highest volatility with daily market movements. Since you are conce about tax saving so it's better you to invest in equity oriented hybrid funds, which are also called balanced funds. These funds invest at least 65 per cent in equity and the rest in debt. The equity allocation of these funds gives them the opportunity for high growth, while the debt component provides a cushion when the equity component fails to perform. However, these funds may look dull, compared to pure equity funds when the markets soar, as they don't fully invest in equity. But they are the best bet of investors looking for a mixture of safety, income and capital appreciation. Therefore choose two good balanced funds and invest in them through SIP. And when it comes to tax savings, There are lots of tax-saving avenues which offers tax savings under the Income Tax Act. These include traditional instruments such as, Public Provident Fund (PPF), National Savings Certificate (NSC), etc., which are considered safe avenues however do not generate returns commensurate to meet one’s financial goals. Alternately, you can can park your funds in Equity-Linked Savings Schemes (ELSS) to save their tax outgo and accumulate returns over the long run . I hope you find my answer helpful. :)

Investing money for the better return is a very smart move a person can make, There many types of investment procedure and all the procedures have different criteria. • 1st being mutual funds:-  Mutual funds are a very well balanced and reliable source to invest some money, We can invest as much money as we want in order to get returns.  Different mutual funds are different than one another and you should always invest in different mutual funds so that if somehow one doesn’t make you money, Others might.  We all have heard this line in any mutual funds Ad in TV or any social media platform “Mutual funds are subjected to market risks, read all the scheme related documents carefully”.  So always double check before investing in mutual funds. • 2nd is Close-End funds:-  A closed-end fund is a portfolio of pooled assets that raises a fixed amount of capital through an initial public offering (IPO) and then lists shares for trade on a stock exchange.  In this, you basically buy and sell the active assets according to it's price of the share on that particular day.  The prices might go downhill or uphill and you might also have to witness the loss but it happens only a few time otherwise IPO is very popular and many people use it to earn. • 3rd is Exchange-Traded funds:-  An exchange-traded fund (ETF) is a collection of securities, such as stocks, that tracks an underlying index. The best-known example is the SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY), which tracks the S&P 500 Index.  ETF share prices fluctuate all day as the ETF is bought and sold; this is different from mutual funds that only trade once a day after the market closes. • 4th is everybody’s favorite “FD”:-  FD is the most successful investment strategy in India, So many people use FD services in so many banks.  FD stores their money in safe vaults and given interest to their clients also and this makes a good deal for the people if they want to earn something by using their money. • There are a lot of small businesses where the money can be invested. • If you have loads of money then you can try real estate or else you can invest in bigger and more successful companies.

The best way to invest Rs. 5 lakhs for maximum and secured returns will be in fixed deposit. A fixed deposit (FD) is an investment plan provided by banks or NBFCs which provides investors with a higher rate of interest than a regular savings account, until the given maturity date. Your money will safe and secured for the entire tenure and you will get your principal amount back at the end of the tenure along with the high interest. But, the problem will arise when you invest the entire Rs. 5 lakhs as FD from one account for 3 years at an interest rate of 7.85%, your yearly interest will be Rs. 43K. TDS is deducted once the interest exceeds the limit of Rs. 10K in one financial year. So, how will you save TDS or tax deduction? You can submit Form 15G/15H, that stats you have no taxable income.You can distribute FD investment in separate banks so that the interest earned does not exceed the Rs. 10,000 limit.You can adjust the timing of the FDs and save TDS.You can invest in FD from different accounts- one from personal account and other from HUF account. This will be treated as different FDs.
